name: Confirmation Bias
description: The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms or supports one's prior beliefs or values.

name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: The tendency to continue an endeavor if an investment in money, effort, or time has already been made, even if the current costs outweigh the expected benefits.

name: Availability Heuristic
description: A mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to a given person's mind when evaluating a specific topic, concept, method or decision.

name: Anchoring Bias
description: The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information offered (the 'anchor') when making decisions.

name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
description: A cognitive bias whereby people with low ability at a task overestimate their ability. It is related to the cognitive bias of illusory superiority and comes from the inability of people to recognize their lack of ability.

name: Fundamental Attribution Error
description: The tendency for people to over-emphasize personality-based explanations for behaviors observed in others while under-emphasizing the role and power of situational influences on the same behavior.

name: Bandwagon Effect
description: The tendency to do or believe things because many other people do or believe the same. Related to groupthink and herd behavior.

name: Self-Serving Bias
description: The tendency to attribute successes to personal factors and failures to situational factors. It is a way of protecting and enhancing self-esteem.

name: Hindsight Bias
description: The tendency, after an event has occurred, to see the event as having been predictable, despite there having been little or no objective basis for predicting it.

name: Negativity Bias
description: The psychological phenomenon by which humans have a greater recall of unpleasant memories compared with positive memories. People are more affected by negative events than positive ones.

name: Framing Effect
description: Drawing different conclusions from the same information, depending on how that information is presented.

name: Choice-supportive Bias
description: The tendency to retroactively ascribe positive attributes to an option you've chosen.

name: Ostrich Effect
description: The decision to ignore dangerous or negative information by 'burying' one's head in the sand, like an ostrich.

name: Outcome Bias
description: Judging a decision based on its eventual outcome instead of on the quality of the decision at the time it was made.

name: Overconfidence
description: The tendency to be more confident in one's own abilities, including decision-making, than is objectively reasonable.

name: Zero-risk Bias
description: Preferring to reduce a small risk to zero over a greater reduction in a larger risk.

name: Halo Effect
description: The tendency for an initial positive impression of a person in one area to positively influence one's opinion of that person in other areas.

name: Actor-observer Bias
description: The tendency to attribute your own actions to external causes while attributing other people's behaviors to internal ones.

name: In-group Favoritism
description: The tendency to favor members of one's own group over out-group members.

name: Spotlight Effect
description: The tendency to overestimate how much other people notice your appearance or behavior.

name: False Memory
description: A psychological phenomenon where a person recalls something that did not happen or recalls it differently from the way it actually happened.

name: Clustering Illusion
description: The tendency to erroneously consider the inevitable 'streaks' or 'clusters' arising in small samples from random distributions to be non-random.

name: Pessimism Bias
description: The tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative things happening to them.

name: Optimism Bias
description: The tendency to be overly optimistic, overestimating the probability of positive outcomes and underestimating the probability of negative outcomes.

name: Action Bias
description: The tendency to favor action over inaction, even when there is no rational reason to do so.

name: Affect Heuristic
description: The tendency to let one's emotions influence decisions.

name: Ambiguity Effect
description: The tendency to avoid options for which missing information makes the probability seem 'unknown'.

name: Attentional Bias
description: The tendency of our perception to be affected by our recurring thoughts.

name: Barnum Effect
description: The tendency to accept certain information as true, such as character assessments or horoscopes, even when the information is so vague as to be worthless.

name: Base Rate Fallacy
description: The tendency to ignore statistical information in favor of using irrelevant information that one believes to be relevant to make a judgment.

name: Belief Perseverance
description: The tendency to maintain a belief even after the information that originally gave rise to it has been discredited.

name: Bikeshedding
description: The tendency to give disproportionate weight to trivial issues.

name: Cognitive Dissonance
description: The mental discomfort experienced by a person who holds two or more contradictory beliefs, ideas, or values.

name: Commitment Bias
description: The tendency to remain committed to our past behaviors, particularly those exhibited publicly, even if they do not have desirable outcomes.

name: Conjunction Fallacy
description: The tendency to assume that specific conditions are more probable than a single general one.

name: Decoy Effect
description: The phenomenon whereby consumers will tend to have a specific change in preference between two options when also presented with a third option that is asymmetrically dominated.

name: Disposition Effect
description: The tendency of investors to sell assets that have increased in value, while keeping assets that have dropped in value.

name: Distinction Bias
description: The tendency to view two options as more dissimilar when evaluating them simultaneously than when evaluating them separately.

name: Effort Justification
description: The tendency to attribute a greater value to an outcome they had to put effort into acquiring or achieving.

name: Empathy Gap
description: The tendency to underestimate the influence or strength of feelings, in either oneself or others.

name: Endowment Effect
description: The tendency for people to ascribe more value to things merely because they own them.

name: False Consensus Effect
description: The tendency for people to overestimate the degree to which others agree with them.

name: Focusing Effect
description: The tendency to place too much importance on one aspect of an event.

name: Frequency Illusion
description: The illusion in which a word, a name, or other thing that has recently come to one's attention suddenly seems to appear with improbable frequency shortly afterwards.

name: Functional Fixedness
description: A cognitive bias that limits a person to using an object only in the way it is traditionally used.

name: Gambler's Fallacy
description: The belief that if a particular event occurs more frequently than normal during the past it is less likely to happen in the future.

name: Groupthink
description: The practice of thinking or making decisions as a group in a way that discourages creativity or individual responsibility.

name: Hard-easy Effect
description: The tendency to overestimate one's ability to perform a difficult task and to underestimate one's ability to perform an easy task.

name: Hot-hand Fallacy
description: The fallacious belief that a person who has experienced success with a random event has a greater chance of further success in additional attempts.

name: IKEA Effect
description: The tendency for people to place a disproportionately high value on products they partially created.

name: Illusion of Control
description: The tendency for people to overestimate their ability to control events.

name: Illusion of Explanatory Depth
description: The illusion that you understand something in detail when in fact you do not.

name: Illusion of Transparency
description: The tendency for people to overestimate the degree to which their personal mental state is known by others.

name: Illusory Correlation
description: The phenomenon of perceiving a relationship between variables even when no such relationship exists.

name: Impact Bias
description: The tendency to overestimate the length or the intensity of future feeling states.

name: Information Bias
description: The tendency to seek information when it does not affect action.

name: Just-world Hypothesis
description: The assumption that a person's actions are inherently inclined to bring morally fair and fitting consequences to that person.

name: Less-is-better Effect
description: A type of preference reversal that occurs when the lesser or smaller alternative of a proposition is preferred when evaluated separately, but not evaluated together.

name: Loss Aversion
description: The tendency to prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains.

name: Mere Exposure Effect
description: The phenomenon by which people tend to develop a preference for things merely because they are familiar with them.

name: Misinformation Effect
description: The tendency for post-event information to interfere with the memory of the original event.

name: Na√Øve Realism
description: The human tendency to believe that we see the world around us objectively, and that people who disagree with us must be uninformed, irrational, or biased.

name: Normalcy Bias
description: The refusal to plan for, or react to, a disaster which has never happened before.

name: Omission Bias
description: The tendency to judge harmful actions as worse, or less moral, than equally harmful omissions.

name: Planning Fallacy
description: The tendency to underestimate the time it will take to complete a task.

name: Post-purchase Rationalization
description: The tendency to persuade oneself through rational argument that a purchase was a good value.

name: Pro-innovation Bias
description: The tendency to have an excessive optimism towards an invention or innovation's usefulness and an excessive pessimism towards its limitations and weaknesses.

name: Projection Bias
description: The tendency to falsely project current preferences onto a future event.

name: Recency Effect
description: The tendency to remember the most recently presented information best.

name: Regret Aversion
description: The tendency to avoid making a decision because you fear that the decision will turn out to be wrong.

name: Restraint Bias
description: The tendency to overestimate one's ability to show restraint in the face of temptation.

name: Rhyme-as-reason Effect
description: The tendency to believe information is more accurate if it's rhyming.

name: Risk Compensation
description: The tendency to take greater risks when perceived safety increases.

name: Salience Bias
description: The tendency to focus on items or information that are more prominent and ignore those that are not.

name: Selective Perception
description: The tendency to not notice and more quickly forget stimuli that cause emotional discomfort and contradict our prior beliefs.

name: Social Desirability Bias
description: The tendency to over-report socially desirable characteristics or behaviors in oneself and under-report socially undesirable characteristics or behaviors.

name: Status Quo Bias
description: The tendency to like things to stay relatively the same.

name: Stereotyping
description: Expecting a member of a group to have certain characteristics without having actual information about that individual.

name: Survivorship Bias
description: The logical error of concentrating on the people or things that 'survived' some process and inadvertently overlooking those that did not because of their lack of visibility.

name: Unit Bias
description: The tendency to want to finish a given unit of a task or an item. Stronger with larger units.

name: Well-traveled Road Effect
description: The tendency of travelers to overestimate the time it will take to travel a new route and underestimate the time it will take to travel a familiar route.

name: Zero-sum Bias
description: A bias whereby a person tends to believe that a situation is zero-sum (i.e., one person's gain is another's loss).
